headline.main: Imitating to Compete, Not to Flatter

docs.lead_paragraph: FROM now through the fall, the county's calendar is chockablock with art, music and cultural festivals. Have you ever wondered what it takes to get one on the map in a community? Those who have done so cite several key factors: a strong idea, a core group of dedicated volunteers and advance planning of up to a year. According to Ron Aja, outreach events director of the 40-year-old Clearwater Festival, which is scheduled for June 17 and 18 at Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson: ''If you're just starting out, you need either a lot of money or a lot of time. If you don't have money, you need a lot of time to put all the pieces together in a way you can afford.'' And keep expectations low, he advises -- at least at the beginning. ''There's a growth process. Unless you can afford big names, you need to let the festival grow organically.''

headline.main: A Lot of Work For a Day in the Park

docs.abstract: Article describes what it takes to organize cultural festivals in Westchester County and put them on calendar; photos (Special Issue: The Arts) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LYLE PUENTE composed a song in a parking lot while waiting to pick up his children from school. Dave Nichols wrote one sitting in his car outside a McDonald's.

headline.main: They've Got The Music in Them

docs.abstract: Profiles of and interviews with Westchester County residents Pete Calamera, retired New York City police officer, Lyle Puente, former freelance illustrator, and David Nichols, who has worked as accountant and in real estate management, all of whom have changed careers and become songwriters; photos (Special Issue: The Arts) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Training to Work in the Home (Someone Else's)'' (Job Market, May 14):
docs.abstract: Letter from Dennis Rivera, president of 1199 SEIU, United Healthcare Workers East, notes his union's efforts to organize and mobilize home health care workers (May 14 article); says there will be no way to attract hundreds of thousands of people to this work unless they are offered livable wage and affordable health care
